clinical_study.brief_title: A Study Comparing the Efficacy of Two Topical Steroid Application Regimens in Pediatric Patients With Atopic Dermatitis
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Investigator-Blinded Study Comparing the Efficacy of Two Topical Steroid Application Regimens in Pediatric Patients With Atopic Dermatitis

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate the efficacy of two different corticosteroid ointment application regimens for the treatment of eczema (atopic dermatitis).

primary_outcome.measure: Efficacy of corticosteroid application regimen as assessed by the Eczema Area and Severity Index (EASI)

secondary_outcome.measure: Effect of corticosteroid ointment application regimens on serum cortisol
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2 weeks after application of topical corticosteroids

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency of atopic dermatitis flares in the 3 months following the two-week treatment regimen
Adverse effects associated with each corticosteroid application regimen
secondary_outcome.description: Characterize and quantify adverse effects associated with each corticosteroid application regimen.

arm_group.description: Application of hydrocortisone 2.5% ointment or triamcinolone acetonide 0.1% ointment immediately to wet skin once a day and dry skin once a day.
Application of hydrocortisone 2.5% ointment or triamcinolone acetonide 0.1% ointment to dry skin twice a day.

intervention.description: Corticosteroid ointment applied to wet skin once a day and dry skin once a day.
Corticosteroid ointment applied to dry skin twice a day.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Meet the clinical criteria for the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis
- Have disease over at least 5% of their total body surface area.
- Less than 18 years of age.
- Families able to comprehend written instructions in English and able to complete questionnaires with assistance if needed.
- Parents/guardians able to understand and willing to sign a parental permission form.
- Children between the ages of 7-17 years willing to sign an age-appropriate assent form.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are allergic or intolerant of the topical medications employed in this study.
- Lack of follow-up after initial visit or regimen noncompliance.
- Patients who do not have access to a bathtub.
